content: this is always my least favorite part of any build but with the technique I used
this time around it was pretty easy and pretty painless hey guys welcome back to
black magic crafts today we are gonna continue on our little Tudor house build
here and I'm going to tackle the shingles this is the most annoying part
of any build and there's a ton of different ways that you can do it
there's a lot of different ways to slice shingles I'm not gonna show them all to
you I'm just going to show you this one because it's a really good method and of
all the ones I've tried this is by far the most efficient least annoying and
actually maybe one of the nicest looking so we're just gonna focus on that one I
do want to point out a few things to keep in mind when deciding on your
technique however there's two main materials you can use for shingles two
really good candidates that's cardstock from things like cereal
boxes and XPS foam and both have their advantages and disadvantages with the
cardstock there's actually a lot of advantages the material is super durable
it's not gonna rip or break or tear so if you have a rambunctious players
you're making things for a club the card stock is going to be infinitely more
durable than foam shingles you also don't need any special tools or
equipment to make them just a blade in a straight edge or even just scissors
they're pretty easy to do and they look pretty decent the downside to cardstock
shingles and the thing that turns me off from them on some builds is that you
can't apply texture to them you cannot do wood grain so if you're trying to do
something that looks like a cedar shake shingle cardstocks not gonna be a very
good option but if you want something that looks like a slate shingles alt or
whatever it's a fantastic option and I've done it
many different buildings with foam the disadvantages are many for one they're
really fragile along the edge the overhang here this is soft and fragile
and if it gets bumped or pulled the wrong way it will break so for club use
orchids not really the best the other
disadvantage is that you do need special equipment to use foam effectively for
shingles there's no way you're gonna do this without a hot wire well you can but
it's a real pain it's not ideal for everyone but the big advantage is that
you can texture it really well to look like wood you can do the wire brush
technique on it and it looks amazing so if you're after a wood shake shingle
foam is really the best candidate the other thing to consider is the two
methods of approach do you make a bunch of individual shingles and put them on
one by one or do you make strips somehow and apply those strips again advantages
and disadvantages to each they're both good in their own respects I prefer
doing strips if possible because it's usually more efficient if you can come
up with a way to make strips look as good as individual ones then good to go
on a small building I might do individual ones like on the hag's Hut I
did individual ones but on a big building strips in my opinion are the
way to go and the method I used on this build is a really efficient and easy way
to do the strip's it looks awesome so let's make some shingles
my idea here was to limit the number of
steps involved in the amount of menial repetition I started with a strip of
half-inch XPS foam that I cut with my Olfa blade I didn't worry about it not
having a straight edge I knew that I wanted these to look like wood shake
shingles and then I'd be adding wood grain to them later so I took note of
the direction of the grain in the foam because when you texture across the
grain it can rip and tear the material using my Olfa knife I cut the divisions
between the shingles then using a smaller exacto blade I started cutting
each segment to a different length and angle this proved to be a lot more
difficult than I thought and my strip actually ended up breaking in a few
spots but mostly I wasn't happy with how thin the kerf from the knife was so I
decided to restart the process this time around I did the same thing but used my
procs on hot wire table this made a slightly wider kerf that would give more
definition to the shingles and it allowed me to cut the length and angles
as I went the hot wire also slightly cauterizes the foam making what will end
up being a very fragile piece slightly stronger once the master strip was
created it was just a matter of adding wood grain and slicing into thin strips
order of operation is really important here if you first cut the thin strip
then add the wood grain the wire brush can easily rip and destroy the strip's
instead I would add the wire brush wood grain to the master strip first then run
the piece through the hot wire and cut my thin sliver then more wire brush on
the master and then rip the sliver rinse repeat rinse repeat while doing this is
a bit tedious it is by far the least annoying and most efficient method I've
done yet and trust me I've done this a lot of different ways when making the
strip's you want them to be as thin as possible think in the area of one
millimeter as a target with a bunch of these strips cut I could finally start
the more fun part of the process actually applying them to the building
for this I use fast grab tacky glue it's a bit
thick and difficult to squeeze out of the bottle but it holds the phone
quickly and makes the overall roof sturdier once it's dry and unlike hot
glue it won't give me a bunch of annoying wisps to clean up after you
want each row shingles to be offset by about half a shingle so that you don't
have continuous lines running up the whole length of the roof I find that
with foam it's best to place the strip first let it overhang the roof then
slice off the excess when overlapping you also want to make
sure you don't leave too much of the previous row exposed in general you want
about two-thirds of the lower row covered it can be tempting to overlap
less to make the process go quicker and use less strips but if you want the
final result to look really good it's important to execute some patience and
willpower here I like to work on both sides of the roof at the same time doing
a few strips on one side then jumping over to the other my single half-inch
thick master strip made enough strips of shingles to do about half of each side
of the roof or the equivalent of one full side I had to make a second one but
keep in mind here that I used half inch material because that's what I had on
hand if I had used one-inch thick material to make my master strip that
would have meant that I could have gotten the entire buildings worth of
shingles from one master I would have only needed to do the master shape
carving once for the whole project which would have been very efficient as that's
the step that takes the longest and is the most difficult you want to make sure
you have your shingles running right up to the ridge line all showing the same
amount of overlap you don't want the last row to show a full face of shingle
that will just look super weird and wrong essentially you need to end with
about a half height strip I like to run the last strip wild and then using a
very sharp brand-new exacto I cut off the excess at the top
to complete the install ridge caps are required these need to be done with
overlapping individual shingles I created one plane master strip that I
textured with the wire brush then I ripped it into a very thin sliver that I
then cut into individual square shingles it's important that the strip be thin
enough that you can fold them in half and create an L shape that rides the
ridge of the roof for this I do begrudgingly switch to hot glue because
even fast grab tacky glue doesn't hold these quickly enough to stop them from
popping up as you work I could stop at this point but there's one thing I like
to do to make the piece look complete even with thin shingles I find that the
way the roof looks from straight on to be kind of sloppy I don't like seeing
the layers of material you could leave this but I prefer to put on a fascia
board to complete the look for this I just ripped thin strips of foam textured
with the wood grain and use hot glue to attach with thin material and hot glue
it's really easy to follow the curvature of the roof as I said there are so many
ways you can approach this task but having done it many times with several
different techniques and orders of operations I'm confident in saying this
is my preferred method at least when doing wood shingles from foam again like
I said cardstock is an excellent option if you aren't set on having wood grain
there you go one whole roof complete this was really painless this time
around I think I did the entire process start to finish in under two hours so
put on a movie and banging out a roof I hope you found this video helpful and
informative if you did please hit that like button and let me know
in the comment section below if you have a preferred method that you really
really love feel free to put it in the comments section let me know what your
favorite process is if you want to pick up any tools or supplies for yourself to
get started in the Hobby you don't have a procs on hotwire table yet and you
finally want to grab one so you can do stuff like this head over to Blackmagic
craft dot CA there I have my essential equipment page and I list all of the
things that I use and recommend and why I use them so that you know you're
buying the right stuff also those links are Amazon affiliate links so when you
buy through them you pay your normal price but I get a small Commission and
that commission helps fund videos like this one the other way these videos are
paid for is through patreon it's the support from people on patreon that
makes it possible for me to make these crafting videos every single Friday for
the community for free for you guys to watch if you get a lot of value out of
these videos that I make please consider joining up and supporting on patreon I'd
love to have you as the newest member of the black magic crafts fellowship that's
it for this one guys I still need to paint this thing so that's likely what
we're gonna do next Friday Cheers have a great weekend everyone see you
next Tuesday for a reviews day peace
